001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004import squidpony.LZSPlus;
005import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
006import squidpony.squidmath.*;
007import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise2D;
008import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise3D;
009import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise4D;
010
011import java.io.Serializable;
012import java.util.Arrays;
013
014/**
015 * Can be used to generate world maps with a wide variety of data, starting with height, temperature and moisture.
016 * From there, you can determine biome information in as much detail as your game needs, with default implementations
017 * available; one assigns a single biome to each cell based on heat/moisture, and the other gives a gradient between two
018 * biome types for every cell. The maps this produces with {@link SphereMap} are valid for spherical world projections,
019 * while the maps from {@link TilingMap} are for toroidal world projections and will wrap from edge to opposite edge
020 * seamlessly thanks to <a href="https://www.gamedev.net/blog/33/entry-2138456-seamless-noise/">a technique from the
021 * Accidental Noise Library</a> that involves getting a 2D slice of 4D Simplex noise. Because of how Simplex noise
022 * works, this also allows extremely high zoom levels for all types of map as long as certain parameters are within
023 * reason. Other world maps produce more conventional shapes, like {@link SpaceViewMap} and {@link RotatingSpaceMap}
024 * make a view of a marble-like world from space, and others make more unconventional shapes, like {@link EllipticalMap}
025 * or {@link EllipticalHammerMap}, which form a 2:1 ellipse shape that accurately keeps sizes but not relative shapes,
026 * {@link RoundSideMap}, which forms a pill-shape, and {@link HyperellipticalMap}, which takes parameters so it can fit
027 * any shape between a circle or ellipse and a rectangle (the default is a slightly squared-off ellipse). You can access
028 * the height map with the {@link #heightData} field, the heat map with the {@link #heatData} field, the moisture map
029 * with the {@link #moistureData} field, and a special map that stores ints representing the codes for various ranges of
030 * elevation (0 to 8 inclusive, with 0 the deepest ocean and 8 the highest mountains) with {@link #heightCodeData}. The
031 * last map should be noted as being the simplest way to find what is land and what is water; any height code 4 or
032 * greater is land, and any height code 3 or less is water.
033 * <br>
034 * Biome mapping is likely to need customization per-game, but some good starting points are {@link SimpleBiomeMapper},
035 * which stores one biome per cell, and {@link DetailedBiomeMapper}, which gives each cell a midway value between two
036 * biomes.
037 */
038@Beta
039public abstract class WorldMapGenerator implements Serializable {
040    private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
041    public final int width, height;
042    public int seedA, seedB, cacheA, cacheB;
043    public GWTRNG rng;
044    public final double[][] heightData, heatData, moistureData;
045    public final GreasedRegion landData;
046    public final int[][] heightCodeData;
047    public double landModifier = -1.0, heatModifier = 1.0,
048            minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
049            minHeightActual = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeightActual = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
050            minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
051            minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
052    protected double centerLongitude = 0.0;
053
054    public int zoom = 0, startX = 0, startY = 0, usedWidth, usedHeight;
055    protected IntVLA startCacheX = new IntVLA(8), startCacheY = new IntVLA(8);
056    protected int zoomStartX = 0, zoomStartY = 0;
057
058    /**
059     * A FastNoise that has a higher frequency than that class defaults to, which is useful for maps here. With the
060     * default FastNoise frequency of 1f/32f, the maps this produces are giant blurs.
061     * <br>
062     * Even though this is a FastNoise and so technically can be edited, that seems to have issues when there's more
063     * than one WorldMapGenerator that uses this field. So you can feel free to use this as a Noise2D or Noise3D when
064     * generators need one, but don't change it too much, if at all.
065     */
066    public static final FastNoise DEFAULT_NOISE = new FastNoise(0x1337CAFE, 1f, FastNoise.SIMPLEX, 1);
067
068    /**
069     * Used to implement most of the copy constructor for subclasses; this cannot copy Noise implementations and leaves
070     * that up to the subclass, but will copy all non-static fields defined in WorldMapGenerator from other.
071     * @param other a WorldMapGenerator (subclass) to copy fields from
072     */
073    protected WorldMapGenerator(WorldMapGenerator other) {
074        width = other.width;
075        height = other.height;
076        usedWidth = other.usedWidth;
077        usedHeight = other.usedHeight;
078        landModifier = other.landModifier;
079        heatModifier = other.heatModifier;
080        minHeat = other.minHeat;
081        maxHeat = other.maxHeat;
082        minHeight = other.minHeight;
083        maxHeight = other.maxHeight;
084        minHeightActual = other.minHeightActual;
085        maxHeightActual = other.maxHeightActual;
086        minWet = other.minWet;
087        maxWet = other.maxWet;
088        centerLongitude = other.centerLongitude;
089        zoom = other.zoom;
090        startX = other.startX;
091        startY = other.startY;
092        startCacheX.addAll(other.startCacheX);
093        startCacheY.addAll(other.startCacheY);
094        zoomStartX = other.zoomStartX;
095        zoomStartY = other.zoomStartY;
096        seedA = other.seedA;
097        seedB = other.seedB;
098        cacheA = other.cacheA;
099        cacheB = other.cacheB;
100        rng = other.rng.copy();
101        heightData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightData);
102        heatData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heatData);
103        moistureData = ArrayTools.copy(other.moistureData);
104        landData = other.landData.copy();
105        heightCodeData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightCodeData);
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Gets the longitude line the map is centered on, which should usually be between 0 and 2 * PI.
110     * @return the longitude line the map is centered on, in radians from 0 to 2 * PI
111     */
112    public double getCenterLongitude() {
113        return centerLongitude;
114    }
115
116    /**
117     * Sets the center longitude line to a longitude measured in radians, from 0 to 2 * PI. Positive arguments will be
118     * corrected with modulo, but negative ones may not always act as expected, and are strongly discouraged.
119     * @param centerLongitude the longitude to center the map projection on, from 0 to 2 * PI (can be any non-negative double).
120     */
121    public void setCenterLongitude(double centerLongitude) {
122        this.centerLongitude = centerLongitude % 6.283185307179586;
123    }
124
125    public static final double
126            deepWaterLower = -1.0, deepWaterUpper = -0.7,        // 0
127            mediumWaterLower = -0.7, mediumWaterUpper = -0.3,    // 1
128            shallowWaterLower = -0.3, shallowWaterUpper = -0.1,  // 2
129            coastalWaterLower = -0.1, coastalWaterUpper = 0.02,   // 3
130            sandLower = 0.02, sandUpper = 0.12,                   // 4
131            grassLower = 0.14, grassUpper = 0.35,                // 5
132            forestLower = 0.35, forestUpper = 0.6,               // 6
133            rockLower = 0.6, rockUpper = 0.8,                    // 7
134            snowLower = 0.8, snowUpper = 1.0;                    // 8
135
136    protected static double removeExcess(double radians)
137    {
138        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
139        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1);
140        return (radians - (floor & -2) - ((floor & 1) << 1)) * (Math.PI);
141//        if(radians < -Math.PI || radians > Math.PI)
142//            System.out.println("UH OH, radians produced: " + radians);
143//        if(Math.random() < 0.00001)
144//            System.out.println(radians);
145//        return radians;
146
147    }
148    /**
149     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
150     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
151     * Always makes a 256x256 map. If you were using {@link WorldMapGenerator#WorldMapGenerator(long, int, int)}, then
152     * this would be the same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256}.
153     */
154    protected WorldMapGenerator()
155    {
156        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256);
157    }
158    /**
159     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
160     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
161     * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
162     * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
163     * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
164     *
165     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
166     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
167     */
168    protected WorldMapGenerator(int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
169    {
170        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight);
171    }
172    /**
173     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
174     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
175     * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
176     * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
177     * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
178     *
179     * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
180     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
181     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
182     */
183    protected WorldMapGenerator(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
184    {
185        width = mapWidth;
186        height = mapHeight;
187        usedWidth = width;
188        usedHeight = height;
189        seedA = (int) (initialSeed & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
190        seedB = (int) (initialSeed >>> 32);
191        cacheA = ~seedA;
192        cacheB = ~seedB;
193        rng = new GWTRNG(seedA, seedB);
194        heightData = new double[width][height];
195        heatData = new double[width][height];
196        moistureData = new double[width][height];
197        landData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
198        heightCodeData = new int[width][height];
199
200//        riverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
201//        lakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
202//        partialRiverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
203//        partialLakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
204//        workingData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
205    }
206
207    /**
208     * Generates a world using a random RNG state and all parameters randomized.
209     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
210     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
211     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
212     */
213    public void generate()
214    {
215        generate(rng.nextLong());
216    }
217
218    /**
219     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long. Other parameters will be randomized, using the same
220     * RNG state to start with.
221     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
222     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
223     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
224     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
225     */
226    public void generate(long state) {
227        generate(-1.0, -1.0, state);
228    }
229
230    /**
231     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long, with specific land and heat modifiers that affect
232     * the land-water ratio and the average temperature, respectively.
233     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
234     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
235     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
236     * @param landMod 1.0 is Earth-like, less than 1 is more-water, more than 1 is more-land; a random value will be used if this is negative
237     * @param heatMod 1.125 is Earth-like, less than 1 is cooler, more than 1 is hotter; a random value will be used if this is negative
238     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
239     */
240    public void generate(double landMod, double heatMod, long state)
241    {
242        if(cacheA != (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL) || cacheB != (int) (state >>> 32) ||
243                landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
244        {
245            seedA = (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
246            seedB = (int) (state >>> 32);
247            zoom = 0;
248            startCacheX.clear();
249            startCacheY.clear();
250            startCacheX.add(0);
251            startCacheY.add(0);
252            zoomStartX = width >> 1;
253            zoomStartY = height >> 1;
254
255        }
256        //System.out.printf("generate, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
257
258        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
259                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
260                usedWidth = (width >> zoom), usedHeight = (height >> zoom), landMod, heatMod, seedA, seedB);
261    }
262
263    /**
264     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
265     * version of zoomOut always zooms out from the center of the currently used area.
266     * <br>
267     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
268     */
269    public void zoomOut()
270    {
271        zoomOut(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
272    }
273    /**
274     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers repeatedly, halving {@code zoomAmount} times; the
275     * 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomOut allows you to specify where the zoom should be
276     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
277     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
278     * <br>
279     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
280     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
281     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
282     */
283    public void zoomOut(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
284    {
285        zoomAmount = Math.min(zoom, zoomAmount);
286        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
287        if(zoomAmount < 0) {
288            zoomIn(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
289            return;
290        }
291        if(zoom > 0)
292        {
293            if(cacheA != seedA || cacheB != seedB)
294            {
295                generate(rng.nextLong());
296            }
297            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
298                    (zoomStartX + (zoomCenterX - (width >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
299                    width >> 1), (width << zoom - zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
300            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
301                    (zoomStartY + (zoomCenterY - (height >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
302                    height >> 1), (height << zoom - zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
303//            System.out.printf("zoomOut, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
304            zoom -= zoomAmount;
305            startCacheX.pop();
306            startCacheY.pop();
307            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.pop() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
308                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
309            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.pop() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
310                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
311//            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartX >> 1) + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
312//                    0), width - (width >> zoom));
313//            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartY >> 1) + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
314//                    0), height - (height >> zoom));
315            regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> zoom + 1), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> zoom + 1),
316                    //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
317                    usedWidth = width >> zoom,  usedHeight = height >> zoom,
318                    landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
319            rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
320        }
321
322    }
323    /**
324     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
325     * version of zoomIn always zooms in to the center of the currently used area.
326     * <br>
327     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
328     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
329     * normal landscape.
330     */
331    public void zoomIn()
332    {
333        zoomIn(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
334    }
335    /**
336     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers repeatedly, doubling {@code zoomAmount} times;
337     * the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomIn allows you to specify where the zoom should be
338     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
339     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
340     * <br>
341     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
342     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
343     * normal landscape.
344     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
345     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
346     */
347    public void zoomIn(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
348    {
349        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
350        if(zoomAmount < 0)
351        {
352            zoomOut(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
353            return;
354        }
355        if(seedA != cacheA || seedB != cacheB)
356        {
357            generate(rng.nextLong());
358        }
359        zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
360                (zoomStartX + zoomCenterX - (width >> 1) << zoomAmount),
361                width >> 1), (width << zoom + zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
362//        int oldZoomY = zoomStartY;
363        zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
364                (zoomStartY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount),
365                height >> 1), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
366//        System.out.printf("zoomIn, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d, oldZoomY: %d, unedited: %d, upperCap: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY,
367//                oldZoomY, (oldZoomY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
368        zoom += zoomAmount;
369        if(startCacheX.isEmpty())
370        {
371            startCacheX.add(0);
372            startCacheY.add(0);
373        }
374        else {
375            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.peek() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom - 1) - (width >> zoom + 1),
376                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
377            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.peek() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom - 1) - (height >> zoom + 1),
378                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
379        }
380        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
381                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
382                usedWidth = width >> zoom, usedHeight = height >> zoom,
383                landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
384        rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
385    }
386
387    protected abstract void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
388                                       double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB);
389    /**
390     * Given a latitude and longitude in radians (the conventional way of describing points on a globe), this gets the
391     * (x,y) Coord on the map projection this generator uses that corresponds to the given lat-lon coordinates. If this
392     * generator does not represent a globe (if it is toroidal, for instance) or if there is no "good way" to calculate
393     * the projection for a given lat-lon coordinate, this returns null. The default implementation always returns null.
394     * If this is a supported operation and the parameters are valid, this returns a Coord with x between 0 and
395     * {@link #width}, and y between 0 and {@link #height}, both exclusive. Automatically wraps the Coord's values using
396     * {@link #wrapX(int, int)} and {@link #wrapY(int, int)}.
397     * @param latitude the latitude, from {@code Math.PI * -0.5} to {@code Math.PI * 0.5}
398     * @param longitude the longitude, from {@code 0.0} to {@code Math.PI * 2.0}
399     * @return the point at the given latitude and longitude, as a Coord with x between 0 and {@link #width} and y between 0 and {@link #height}, or null if unsupported
400     */
401    public Coord project(double latitude, double longitude)
402    {
403        return null;
404    }
405
406    public int codeHeight(final double high)
407    {
408        if(high < deepWaterUpper)
409            return 0;
410        if(high < mediumWaterUpper)
411            return 1;
412        if(high < shallowWaterUpper)
413            return 2;
414        if(high < coastalWaterUpper)
415            return 3;
416        if(high < sandUpper)
417            return 4;
418        if(high < grassUpper)
419            return 5;
420        if(high < forestUpper)
421            return 6;
422        if(high < rockUpper)
423            return 7;
424        return 8;
425    }
426    protected final int decodeX(final int coded)
427    {
428        return coded % width;
429    }
430    protected final int decodeY(final int coded)
431    {
432        return coded / width;
433    }
434    public int wrapX(final int x, final int y)  {
435        return (x + width) % width;
436    }
437    public int wrapY(final int x, final int y)  {
438        return (y + height) % height;
439    }

698
699    public interface BiomeMapper
700    {
701        /**
702         * Gets the most relevant biome code for a given x,y point on the map. Some mappers can store more than one
703         * biome at a location, but only the one with the highest influence will be returned by this method. Biome codes
704         * are always ints, and are typically between 0 and 60, both inclusive; they are meant to be used as indices
705         * into a table of names or other objects that identify a biome, accessible via {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}.
706         * Although different classes may define biome codes differently, they should all be able to be used as indices
707         * into the String array returned by getBiomeNameTable().
708         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
709         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
710         * @return an int that can be used as an index into the array returned by {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}
711         */
712        int getBiomeCode(int x, int y);
713
714        /**
715         * Gets a heat code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
716         * implementations may use more or less detail for heat codes, but 0 is always the coldest code used, and the
717         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the hottest code used.
718         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
719         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
720         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how hot an area is, with 0 as coldest
721         */
722        int getHeatCode(int x, int y);
723        /**
724         * Gets a moisture code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
725         * implementations may use more or less detail for moisture codes, but 0 is always the driest code used, and the
726         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the wettest code used. Some
727         * implementations may allow seasonal change in moisture, e.g. monsoon seasons, to be modeled differently from
728         * average precipitation in an area, but the default assumption is that this describes the average amount of
729         * moisture (rain, humidity, and possibly snow/hail or other precipitation) that an area receives annually.
730         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
731         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
732         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how much moisture an area tends to receive, with 0 as driest
733         */
734        int getMoistureCode(int x, int y);
735
736        /**
737         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to. A
738         * sample table is in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper#biomeTable}; the 61-element array format documented for that
739         * field is encouraged for implementing classes if they use 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and track
740         * rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained
741         * with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}, or for some implementing classes other methods may provide more
742         * detailed information.
743         * @return a String array that often contains 61 elements, to be used with biome codes as indices.
744         */
745        String[] getBiomeNameTable();
746        /**
747         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
748         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
749         * retrieved with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)} and used as indices into {@link #getBiomeNameTable()} or a
750         * custom biome table.
751         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
752         */
753        void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world);
754    }
755    /**
756     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you only need a single value to describe a biome, such
757     * as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest".
758     * <br>
759     * To use: 1, Construct a SimpleBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
760     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
761     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used as an index
762     * into the {@link #biomeTable} static field to get a String name for a biome type, or used with an alternate biome
763     * table of your design. Biome tables in this case are 61-element arrays organized into groups of 6 elements, with
764     * the last element reserved for empty space where the map doesn't cover (as with some map projections). Each
765     * group goes from the coldest temperature first to the warmest temperature last in the group. The first group of 6
766     * contains the dryest biomes, the next 6 are medium-dry, the next are slightly-dry, the next slightly-wet, then
767     * medium-wet, then wettest. After this first block of dry-to-wet groups, there is a group of 6 for coastlines, a
768     * group of 6 for rivers, a group of 6 for lakes, a group of 6 for oceans, and then one element for space outside
769     * the map. The last element, with code 60, is by convention the String "Empty", but normally the code should be
770     * enough to tell that a space is off-map. This also assigns moisture codes and heat codes from 0 to 5 for each
771     * cell, which may be useful to simplify logic that deals with those factors.
772     */
773    public static class SimpleBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
774    {
775        /**
776         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
777         */
778        public int[][] heatCodeData,
779        /**
780         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
781         */
782        moistureCodeData,
783        /**
784         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 60 inclusive. You can use {@link #biomeTable} to look up
785         * String names for biomes, or construct your own table as you see fit (see docs in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}).
786         */
787        biomeCodeData;
788
789        @Override
790        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
791            return biomeCodeData[x][y];
792        }
793
794        @Override
795        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
796            return heatCodeData[x][y];
797        }
798
799        @Override
800        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
801            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
802        }
803
804        /**
805         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
806         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
807         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
808         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
809         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
810         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
811         */
812        @Override
813        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
814            return biomeTable;
815        }
816
817        public static final double
818                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
819                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
820                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
821                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,    // 3
822                warmerValueLower = 0.69,   warmerValueUpper = 0.85,  // 4
823                warmestValueLower = 0.85,  warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
824
825        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
826                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
827                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
828                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
829                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
830                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
831
832        /**
833         * The default biome table to use with biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned based on
834         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
835         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
836         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest), then oceans (coldest to warmest), and
837         * lastly a single "biome" for empty space outside the map (meant for projections that don't fill a rectangle).
838         */
839        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
840                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
841                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
842                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
843                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
844                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
845                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
846                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
847                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
848                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
849                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
850                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
851                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
852        };
853
854        /**
855         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
856         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
857         */
858        public SimpleBiomeMapper()
859        {
860            heatCodeData = null;
861            moistureCodeData = null;
862            biomeCodeData = null;
863        }
864
865        /**
866         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
867         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
868         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used as indices into {@link #biomeTable} or a custom biome table.
869         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
870         */
871        @Override
872        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
873            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
874                return;
875            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
876                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
877            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
878                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
879            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
880                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
881            final double i_hot = (world.maxHeat == world.minHeat) ? 1.0 : 1.0 / (world.maxHeat - world.minHeat);
882            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
883                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
884                    final double hot = (world.heatData[x][y] - world.minHeat) * i_hot, moist = world.moistureData[x][y];
885                    final int heightCode = world.heightCodeData[x][y];
886                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
887                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
888                        continue;
889                    }
890                    int hc, mc;
891                    boolean isLake = false,// world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
892                            isRiver = false;// world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
893                    if(heightCode < 4) {
894                        mc = 9;
895                    }
896                    else if (moist > wetterValueUpper) {
897                        mc = 5;
898                    } else if (moist > wetValueUpper) {
899                        mc = 4;
900                    } else if (moist > dryValueUpper) {
901                        mc = 3;
902                    } else if (moist > drierValueUpper) {
903                        mc = 2;
904                    } else if (moist > driestValueUpper) {
905                        mc = 1;
906                    } else {
907                        mc = 0;
908                    }
909
910                    if (hot > warmerValueUpper) {
911                        hc = 5;
912                    } else if (hot > warmValueUpper) {
913                        hc = 4;
914                    } else if (hot > coldValueUpper) {
915                        hc = 3;
916                    } else if (hot > colderValueUpper) {
917                        hc = 2;
918                    } else if (hot > coldestValueUpper) {
919                        hc = 1;
920                    } else {
921                        hc = 0;
922                    }
923
924                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
925                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
926                    biomeCodeData[x][y] = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
927                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
928                }
929            }
930        }
931    }
932    /**
933     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you want an area's biome to be a combination of two
934     * main biome types, such as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest", with the biomes varying in weight between areas.
935     * <br>
936     * To use: 1, Construct a DetailedBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
937     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
938     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used with the
939     * extract methods in this class to get various information from it (these are {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
940     * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, {@link #extractPartA(int)}, {@link #extractPartB(int)}, and
941     * {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}). You can get predefined names for biomes using the extractBiome methods (these
942     * names can be changed in {@link #biomeTable}), or raw indices into some (usually 61-element) collection or array
943     * with the extractPart methods. The extractMixAmount() method gets a float that is the amount by which biome B
944     * affects biome A; if this is higher than 0.5, then biome B is the "dominant" biome in the area.
945     */
946    public static class DetailedBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
947    {
948        /**
949         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
950         */
951        public int[][] heatCodeData,
952        /**
953         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
954         */
955        moistureCodeData,
956        /**
957         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, using one int to store the codes for two biomes and the degree by which
958         * the second biome affects the first. These codes can be used with methods in this class like
959         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two
960         * dominant biomes in an area, called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B
961         * affects biome A.
962         */
963        biomeCodeData;
964
965
966        /**
967         * Gets the biome code for the dominant biome at a given x,y position. This is equivalent to getting the raw
968         * biome code from {@link #biomeCodeData}, calling {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} on that raw biome code, and
969         * chooosing whether to call {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} based on whether the mix
970         * amount is lower than 0.5 (yielding part A) or higher (yielding part B).
971         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
972         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
973         * @return the biome code for the dominant biome part at the given location
974         */
975        @Override
976        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
977            int code = biomeCodeData[x][y];
978            if(code < 0x2000000) return code & 1023;
979            return (code >>> 10) & 1023;
980        }
981
982        @Override
983        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
984            return heatCodeData[x][y];
985        }
986
987        @Override
988        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
989            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
990        }
991
992        /**
993         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
994         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
995         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
996         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
997         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
998         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
999         */
1000        @Override
1001        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
1002            return biomeTable;
1003        }
1004
1005        public static final double
1006                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
1007                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
1008                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
1009                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,     // 3
1010                warmerValueLower = 0.69,    warmerValueUpper = 0.85,   // 4
1011                warmestValueLower = 0.85,   warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
1012
1013        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
1014                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
1015                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
1016                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
1017                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
1018                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
1019
1020        /**
1021         * The default biome table to use with parts of biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned by
1022         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
1023         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
1024         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest). The last is reserved for empty space.
1025         * <br>
1026         * Unlike with {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}, you cannot use a biome code directly from biomeCodeData as an index
1027         * into this in almost any case; you should pass the biome code to one of the extract methods.
1028         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)} or {@link #extractBiomeB(int)} will work if you want a biome name, or
1029         * {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} should be used if you want a non-coded int that
1030         * represents one of the biomes' indices into something like this. You can also get the amount by which biome B
1031         * is affecting biome A with {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}.
1032         */
1033        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
1034                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
1035                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
1036                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
1037                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
1038                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
1039                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
1040                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
1041                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
1042                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
1043                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
1044                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
1045                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
1046        };
1047
1048        /**
1049         * Gets the int stored in part A of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1050         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1051         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1052         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1053         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part A; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1054         */
1055        public int extractPartA(int biomeCode)
1056        {
1057            return biomeCode & 1023;
1058        }
1059        /**
1060         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part A of the given biome code.
1061         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1062         * @return a String that names the biome in part A of biomeCode, or "Empty" if none can be found
1063         */
1064        public String extractBiomeA(int biomeCode)
1065        {
1066            biomeCode &= 1023;
1067            if(biomeCode < 60)
1068                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1069            return "Empty";
1070        }
1071        /**
1072         * Gets the int stored in part B of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1073         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1074         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1075         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1076         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part B; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1077         */
1078        public int extractPartB(int biomeCode)
1079        {
1080            return (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1081        }
1082
1083        /**
1084         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part B of the given biome code.
1085         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1086         * @return a String that names the biome in part B of biomeCode, or "Ocean" if none can be found
1087         */
1088        public String extractBiomeB(int biomeCode)
1089        {
1090            biomeCode = (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1091            if(biomeCode < 60)
1092                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1093            return "Empty";
1094        }
1095
1096        /**
1097         * This gets the portion of a biome code that represents the amount of mixing between two biomes.
1098         * Biome codes are normally obtained from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, and aren't very usable on their own
1099         * without calling methods like this, {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, and {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}. This returns
1100         * a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive), with 0.0f meaning biome B has no effect on an area and
1101         * biome A is the only one used, 0.5f meaning biome A and biome B have equal effect, and 0.75f meaning biome B
1102         * has most of the effect, three-fourths of the area, and biome A has less, one-fourth of the area.
1103         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1104         * @return a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive) representing mixing of biome B into biome A
1105         */
1106        public float extractMixAmount(int biomeCode)
1107        {
1108            return (biomeCode >>> 20) * 0x1p-10f;
1109        }
1110
1111        /**
1112         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
1113         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
1114         */
1115        public DetailedBiomeMapper()
1116        {
1117            heatCodeData = null;
1118            moistureCodeData = null;
1119            biomeCodeData = null;
1120        }
1121
1122        /**
1123         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
1124         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
1125         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used with methods in this class like {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
1126         * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two dominant biomes in an area,
1127         * called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B affects biome A.
1128         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
1129         */
1130        @Override
1131        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
1132            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
1133                return;
1134            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1135                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1136            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1137                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1138            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1139                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1140            final int[][] heightCodeData = world.heightCodeData;
1141            final double[][] heatData = world.heatData, moistureData = world.moistureData, heightData = world.heightData;
1142            int hc, mc, heightCode, bc;
1143            double hot, moist, high, i_hot = 1.0 / world.maxHeat;
1144            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
1145                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
1146
1147                    heightCode = heightCodeData[x][y];
1148                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
1149                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
1150                        continue;
1151                    }
1152                    hot = heatData[x][y];
1153                    moist = moistureData[x][y];
1154                    high = heightData[x][y];
1155//                    fresh = world.freshwaterData[x][y];
1156                    boolean isLake = false,//world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
1157                            isRiver = false;//world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
1158                    if (moist >= (wettestValueUpper - (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1159                        mc = 5;
1160                    } else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper - (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1161                        mc = 4;
1162                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper - (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1163                        mc = 3;
1164                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper - (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1165                        mc = 2;
1166                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper - (driestValueUpper) * 0.2)) {
1167                        mc = 1;
1168                    } else {
1169                        mc = 0;
1170                    }
1171
1172                    if (hot >= (warmestValueUpper - (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1173                        hc = 5;
1174                    } else if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper - (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1175                        hc = 4;
1176                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper - (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1177                        hc = 3;
1178                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper - (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1179                        hc = 2;
1180                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper - (coldestValueUpper) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1181                        hc = 1;
1182                    } else {
1183                        hc = 0;
1184                    }
1185
1186                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
1187                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
1188                    bc = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
1189                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
1190
1191                    if(heightCode < 4) {
1192                        mc = 9;
1193                    }
1194                    else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper + (wettestValueUpper - wettestValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1195                        mc = 5;
1196                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper + (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1197                        mc = 4;
1198                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper + (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1199                        mc = 3;
1200                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper + (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1201                        mc = 2;
1202                    } else if (moist >= (driestValueUpper + (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1203                        mc = 1;
1204                    } else {
1205                        mc = 0;
1206                    }
1207
1208                    if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper + (warmestValueUpper - warmestValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1209                        hc = 5;
1210                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper + (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1211                        hc = 4;
1212                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper + (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1213                        hc = 3;
1214                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper + (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1215                        hc = 2;
1216                    } else if (hot >= (coldestValueUpper + (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1217                        hc = 1;
1218                    } else {
1219                        hc = 0;
1220                    }
1221
1222                    bc |= (hc + mc * 6) << 10;
1223                    if(heightCode < 4)
1224                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)((heightData[x][y] + 1.0) * 1000.0) << 20;
1225                    else if (isRiver || isLake)
1226                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)(moist * 358.4 + 665.0) << 20;
1227                    else
1228                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int) ((heightCode == 4)
1229                                ? (sandUpper - high) * 10240.0 // multiplier affected by changes to sandLower
1230                                : NumberTools.sway((high + moist) * (4.1 + high - hot)) * 512 + 512) << 20;
1231                }
1232            }
1233        }
1234    }
1235
1236    /**
1237     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that tiles both east-to-west and north-to-south. It tends
1238     * to not appear distorted like {@link SphereMap} does in some areas, even though this is inaccurate for a
1239     * rectangular projection of a spherical world (that inaccuracy is likely what players expect in a map, though).
1240     * You may want {@link LocalMap} instead, for non-world maps that don't tile.
1241     * <a href="http://squidpony.github.io/SquidLib/TilingMap.png" >Example map</a>.
1242     */
1243    public static class TilingMap extends WorldMapGenerator {
1244        //protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.5, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.8, moistureFreq = 2.9, otherFreq = 4.5;
1245//        protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.175, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.3, moistureFreq = 2.4, otherFreq = 3.5;
1246        protected static final double terrainFreq = 0.95, terrainRidgedFreq = 3.1, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375;
1247        private double minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1248                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1249                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1250
1251        public final Noise4D terrain, terrainRidged, heat, moisture, otherRidged;
1252
1253        /**
1254         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1255         * as north-to-south. Always makes a 256x256 map.
1256         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1257         * If you were using {@link TilingMap#TilingMap(long, int, int, Noise4D, double)}, then this would be the
1258         * same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0}.
1259         */
1260        public TilingMap() {
1261            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1262        }
1263
1264        /**
1265         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1266         * as north-to-south.
1267         * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
1268         * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
1269         * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1270         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1271         *
1272         * @param mapWidth  the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1273         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1274         */
1275        public TilingMap(int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1276            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1277        }
1278
1279        /**
1280         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1281         * as north-to-south.
1282         * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
1283         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
1284         * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1285         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1286         *
1287         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1288         * @param mapWidth    the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1289         * @param mapHeight   the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1290         */
1291        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1292            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1293        }
1294
1295        /**
1296         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1297         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and a noise generator (a
1298         * {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}. The {@code initialSeed}
1299         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call
1300         * {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom
1301         * in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1302         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1303         * times. The detail level, which is the {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter that can be passed to another
1304         * constructor, is always 1.0 with this constructor.
1305         *
1306         * @param initialSeed      the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1307         * @param mapWidth         the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1308         * @param mapHeight        the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1309         * @param noiseGenerator   an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, recommended to be {@link FastNoise#instance}
1310         */
1311        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator) {
1312            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, noiseGenerator, 1.0);
1313        }
1314
1315        /**
1316         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1317         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and parameters for noise
1318         * generation (a {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}, and a
1319         * multiplier on how many octaves of noise to use, with 1.0 being normal (high) detail and higher multipliers
1320         * producing even more detailed noise when zoomed-in). The {@code initialSeed} parameter may or may not be used,
1321         * since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map
1322         * cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1323         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1324         * times. The {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter should probably be no lower than 0.5, but can be arbitrarily
1325         * high if you're willing to spend much more time on generating detail only noticeable at very high zoom;
1326         * normally 1.0 is fine and may even be too high for maps that don't require zooming.
1327         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1328         * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1329         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1330         * @param noiseGenerator an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, almost always {@link FastNoise}
1331         * @param octaveMultiplier used to adjust the level of detail, with 0.5 at the bare-minimum detail and 1.0 normal
1332         */
1333        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator, double octaveMultiplier) {
1334            super(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight);
1335            terrain = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 8), terrainFreq);
1336            terrainRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 10), terrainRidgedFreq);
1337            heat = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 3), heatFreq);
1338            moisture = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 4), moistureFreq);
1339            otherRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 6), otherFreq);
1340        }
1341
1342        /**
1343         * Copies the TilingMap {@code other} to construct a new one that is exactly the same. References will only be
1344         * shared to Noise classes.
1345         * @param other a TilingMap to copy
1346         */
1347        public TilingMap(TilingMap other)
1348        {
1349            super(other);
1350            terrain = other.terrain;
1351            terrainRidged = other.terrainRidged;
1352            heat = other.heat;
1353            moisture = other.moisture;
1354            otherRidged = other.otherRidged;
1355            minHeat0 = other.minHeat0;
1356            maxHeat0 = other.maxHeat0;
1357            minHeat1 = other.minHeat1;
1358            maxHeat1 = other.maxHeat1;
1359            minWet0 = other.minWet0;
1360            maxWet0 = other.maxWet0;
1361        }
1362
1363        protected void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
1364                                  double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB)
1365        {
1366            boolean fresh = false;
1367            if(cacheA != stateA || cacheB != stateB || landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
1368            {
1369                minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1370                maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1371                minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1372                maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1373                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1374                maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1375                minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1376                maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1377                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1378                maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1379                minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1380                maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1381                cacheA = stateA;
1382                cacheB = stateB;
1383                fresh = true;
1384            }
1385            rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
1386            long seedA = rng.nextLong(), seedB = rng.nextLong(), seedC = rng.nextLong();
1387            int t;
1388
1389            landModifier = (landMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.1875) + 0.99 : landMod;
1390            heatModifier = (heatMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.45) * (rng.nextDouble()-0.5) + 1.1 : heatMod;
1391
1392            double p, q,
1393                    ps, pc,
1394                    qs, qc,
1395                    h, temp,
1396                    i_w = 6.283185307179586 / width, i_h = 6.283185307179586 / height,
1397                    xPos = startX, yPos = startY, i_uw = usedWidth / (double)width, i_uh = usedHeight / (double)height;
1398            double[] trigTable = new double[width << 1];
1399            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++, xPos += i_uw) {
1400                p = xPos * i_w;
1401                trigTable[x<<1]   = NumberTools.sin(p);
1402                trigTable[x<<1|1] = NumberTools.cos(p);
1403            }
1404            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1405                q = yPos * i_h;
1406                qs = NumberTools.sin(q);
1407                qc = NumberTools.cos(q);
1408                for (int x = 0, xt = 0; x < width; x++) {
1409                    ps = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.sin(p);
1410                    pc = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.cos(p);
1411                    heightData[x][y] = (h = terrain.getNoiseWithSeed(pc +
1412                                    terrainRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs,seedB - seedA) * 0.25,
1413                            ps, qc, qs, seedA) + landModifier - 1.0);
1414                    heatData[x][y] = (p = heat.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc
1415                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedB + seedC)
1416                            , qs, seedB));
1417                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = moisture.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs
1418                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedC + seedA)
1419                            , seedC));
1420                    minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, h);
1421                    maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, h);
1422                    if(fresh) {
1423                        minHeight = Math.min(minHeight, h);
1424                        maxHeight = Math.max(maxHeight, h);
1425
1426                        minHeat0 = Math.min(minHeat0, p);
1427                        maxHeat0 = Math.max(maxHeat0, p);
1428
1429                        minWet0 = Math.min(minWet0, temp);
1430                        maxWet0 = Math.max(maxWet0, temp);
1431
1432                    }
1433                }
1434                minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, minHeight);
1435                maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, maxHeight);
1436
1437            }
1438            double heightDiff = 2.0 / (maxHeightActual - minHeightActual),
1439                    heatDiff = 0.8 / (maxHeat0 - minHeat0),
1440                    wetDiff = 1.0 / (maxWet0 - minWet0),
1441                    hMod,
1442                    halfHeight = (height - 1) * 0.5, i_half = 1.0 / halfHeight;
1443            double minHeightActual0 = minHeightActual;
1444            double maxHeightActual0 = maxHeightActual;
1445            yPos = startY;
1446            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1447            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1448
1449            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1450                temp = Math.abs(yPos - halfHeight) * i_half;
1451                temp *= (2.4 - temp);
1452                temp = 2.2 - temp;
1453                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1454//                    heightData[x][y] = (h = (heightData[x][y] - minHeightActual) * heightDiff - 1.0);
1455//                    minHeightActual0 = Math.min(minHeightActual0, h);
1456//                    maxHeightActual0 = Math.max(maxHeightActual0, h);
1457                    h = heightData[x][y];
1458                    heightCodeData[x][y] = (t = codeHeight(h));
1459                    hMod = 1.0;
1460                    switch (t) {
1461                        case 0:
1462                        case 1:
1463                        case 2:
1464                        case 3:
1465                            h = 0.4;
1466                            hMod = 0.2;
1467                            break;
1468                        case 6:
1469                            h = -0.1 * (h - forestLower - 0.08);
1470                            break;
1471                        case 7:
1472                            h *= -0.25;
1473                            break;
1474                        case 8:
1475                            h *= -0.4;
1476                            break;
1477                        default:
1478                            h *= 0.05;
1479                    }
1480                    heatData[x][y] = (h = (((heatData[x][y] - minHeat0) * heatDiff * hMod) + h + 0.6) * temp);
1481                    if (fresh) {
1482                        ps = Math.min(ps, h); //minHeat0
1483                        pc = Math.max(pc, h); //maxHeat0
1484                    }
1485                }
1486            }
1487            if(fresh)
1488            {
1489                minHeat1 = ps;
1490                maxHeat1 = pc;
1491            }
1492            heatDiff = heatModifier / (maxHeat1 - minHeat1);
1493            qs = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1494            qc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1495            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1496            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1497
1498
1499            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1500                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1501                    heatData[x][y] = (h = ((heatData[x][y] - minHeat1) * heatDiff));
1502                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = (moistureData[x][y] - minWet0) * wetDiff);
1503                    if (fresh) {
1504                        qs = Math.min(qs, h);
1505                        qc = Math.max(qc, h);
1506                        ps = Math.min(ps, temp);
1507                        pc = Math.max(pc, temp);
1508                    }
1509                }
1510            }
1511            if(fresh)
1512            {
1513                minHeat = qs;
1514                maxHeat = qc;
1515                minWet = ps;
1516                maxWet = pc;
1517            }
1518            landData.refill(heightCodeData, 4, 999);
1519            /*
1520            if(generateRivers) {
1521                if (fresh) {
1522                    addRivers();
1523                    riverData.connect8way().thin().thin();
1524                    lakeData.connect8way().thin();
1525                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1526                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1527                } else {
1528                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1529                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1530                    int stx = (zoomStartX >> (zoom)) - (width >> 1),
1531                            sty = (zoomStartY >> (zoom)) - (height >> 1);
1532                    for (int i = 1; i <= zoom; i++) {
1533//                        int stx = (startCacheX.get(i) - startCacheX.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1),
1534//                                sty = (startCacheY.get(i) - startCacheY.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1);
1535                        if ((i & 3) == 3) {
1536                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1537                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.4));
1538                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1539                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.55));
1540                        } else {
1541                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1542                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.5));
1543                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1544                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.7));
1545                        }
1546                    }
1547                }
1548            }
1549            */
1550        }
1551    }
1552
1553    /**
1554     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that distorts the map as it nears the poles, expanding the
1555     * smaller-diameter latitude lines in extreme north and south regions so they take up the same space as the equator;
1556     * this counteracts certain artifacts that are common in Simplex noise world maps by using a 4D noise call to
1557     * generate terrain, using a normal 3D noise call's result as the extra 4th dimension. This generator allows
1558     * choosing a {@link Noise3D}, which is used for most of the generation. This is ideal for projecting onto a 3D
1559     * sphere, which could squash the poles to counteract the stretch this does. You might also want to produce an oval
1560     * map that more-accurately represents the changes in the diameter of a latitude line on a spherical world; you
1561     * should use {@link EllipticalMap} or {@link EllipticalHammerMap} for this.
